title: Question 60

children: A 19-year-old woman presents to the student health center to establish care. She reports four male sexual partners over the past year with inconsistent condom use. She was diagnosed with chlamydia at age 18 years; she has not been screened for sexually transmitted infections since that time. She is up to date on all recommended vaccinations. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive.
On physical examination, vital signs and physical examination are normal.
Which of the following sexually transmitted diseases should the patient be screened for now?

text.__html: Chlamydia, gonorrhea, HIV, herpes simplex virus

children: Persons at high risk for sexually transmitted infections include those who are younger than 25 years; inconsistent condom use; having a new sex partner or multiple sexual partners; having a partner with a recently treated sexually transmitted infection; having sex with a sex worker; sex with anonymous partners; or trading sex for drugs or money.
Patients at high risk for sexually transmitted infections should be screened for chlamydia, gonorrhea, syphilis, and HIV infection.
This sexually active young woman should be screened for chlamydia, gonorrhea, HIV infection, and syphilis (

). She is younger than 25 years and at high risk for sexually transmitted infections (STIs) because she has multiple partners and inconsistently uses condoms. Other risk factors include a new sex partner in the previous 60 days; having sex with a partner recently treated for an STI; sex for money or drugs; sex with sex workers; and sex with anonymous partners. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening for syphilis in all pregnant women and in nonpregnant adults and adolescents at high risk for STIs. Half of STIs diagnosed are in the 15- to 24-year age range, underscoring the importance of screening in this age group. Her age and high-risk STI status necessitate screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea; HIV testing would also be recommended (
), as would syphilis screening. Additionally, counseling regarding the importance of condom use to decrease STI risk is critical.

Because of the length of time since her infection was treated and her ongoing risk factors, testing for chlamydia alone would be inappropriate at this time.
Although she is clearly at risk for herpes simplex virus (HSV), the USPSTF recommends against screening with type-specific antibodies for HSV-1 and HSV-2 (
) in asymptomatic adolescents and adults, including pregnant women.

The incidence of the three reportable bacterial STIs, syphilis, gonorrhea, and chlamydia, has increased at an alarming rate in the United States. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported a 19% increase in chlamydia infections, 63% increase in gonorrhea infections, and 71% increase in primary and secondary syphilis between 2014 and 2018. Of grave concern is the increase in congenital syphilis, with 1306 cases reported in 2018, an increase of 185% compared with 2014.

references: Levy SB, Gunta J, Edemekong P. Screening for sexually transmitted diseases. Prim Care. 2019;46:157-173.
